question: The 10:15 event's been moved inside to the Indian Treaty Room.
answer: The 10:15 is American Fisheries?

question: Yes, sir. They're giving you a 200-pound halibut.
answer: Janie, make a note. We need to schedule more events where somebody gives me a really big fish.

question: Yes, sir.
answer: Janie, I was kidding.

question: Of course, sir.
answer: Hey, Cooper.

question: Mr. Rothschild asked to have a moment with you this morning.
answer: Is he upset about the speech last night?

question: He seemed concerned.
answer: Well, it wouldn't be a Monday morning unless Lewis was concerned about something I did Sunday night.

question: Well, it wouldn't be a Monday morning unless Lewis was concerned about something I did Sunday night.
answer: You skipped the whole paragraph.

question: And Monday morning it is.
answer: "American can no longer afford to pretend that they live in a great society"...and then nothing. You dumped the whole handguns paragraph.

question: This is a time for prudence, Lewis.
answer: That was the kick-ass section.

question: I thought what with being the President and all...
answer: Sir, of course I didn't mean to imply--

question: I thought you'd be turning cartwheels this morning, Lewis -- 63 percent job approval.
answer: That's great news, sir, but...

question: 'Morning, Charlie.
answer: Sir, the press is gonna need an explanation.

question: For what?
answer: Because you dropped the whole kick-ass section, now we've got this thing hanging out there.

question: There's a thing hanging out there?
answer: "Americans can no longer afford to pretend that they live in a great society." Then ...nothing. No explanation. No context. So now it's just this thing.

question: And it's hanging out there?
answer: Yes, sir.

question: Maria-- Did they tell you I'm gonna need-- Thanks.
answer: Mr. President, I really feel we need to focus on...

question: Lewis, however much coffee you drink in the morning, I want you to reduce it by half.
answer: I don't drink coffee.

question: Good morning, Mr. President.
answer: How're you, Mrs. Chapil?

question: Fine, thank you, sir. Mr. Kodak left the detailed breakdown of the approval poll for you. He seemed to indicate that it was very good news.
answer: Sixty-three percent of it, at any rate.

question: --the museum trip. I'll go get it.
answer: What time does she get home today?

question: Three-twenty.
answer: How's my afternoon look?

question: Very crowded.
answer: Schedule some time for me at 3:30. Too-tall McCall, how was Mexico?

question: Sorry! Sorry, my fault. Excuse me. Good morning, Mr. President.
answer: You all right?

question: They keep moving that big ficus plant.
answer: Okay. First, I wanted to say congratulations. Three years ago, we were elected to the White House by one of the narrowest margins in history, and today Kodak tells us 63 percent of registered voters think we're doing a good job.

question: Wait a second. You wanted me to poll registered voters?
answer: But the poll also tells us what we already knew

question: You wanted to see me?
answer: I just got off the phone with A.J. MacInerney.

question: Did the President read the letter?
answer: The President's pissed as hell, Susan. That letter was a stupid move.

question: It was aggressive, and we should stand by every--
answer: This isn't the guy who needed us four years ago, Susan. He's incredibly popular. He's gonna win re-election in a walk, and he could give a shit what we stand by! If the President passes the most important piece of environmental legislation in history, and does it despite our negative endorsement, our political weight in the future will rank somewhere below the Save the Spotted Owl Society. I'm bringing in some help.

question: We don't need another environmental expert to confirm what every other environmental expert--
answer: Not an environmental expert, a professional political strategist. We're playing hardball with Andrew Shepherd, and we need a heavy bat.

question: Who?
answer: Sydney Ellen Wade.

question: Oh Christ. That woman doesn't know the first thing about the environmental lobby.
answer: She's a closer, Susan. She gets the job done.

question: Robin, don't worry about it. No, keep going. I liked what you were playing? What's it called?
answer: Scales.

question: Well... you play it with gusto!
answer: Are my lips swollen?

question: Are they supposed to be?
answer: Yeah.

question: Then you're doing fine.
answer: Whatcha got behind your back?

question: A little gift.
answer: Is it a dirt bike?

question: Nope.
answer: Is it a really old seventh-grade textbook of yours that you're gonna make me read cover to cover and discuss at dinner and drive me crazy with?

question: I'm not comfortable with the "really old" part, but everything else you said was true.
answer: "Understanding the Constitution."

question: Your social studies teacher said your class would be starting on the Constitution this week.
answer: You talked to Mr. Linder?

question: Yes. It's called a Parent-Teacher Conference. Mr. Linder and I were the key player in that discussion. Why don't you like social studies, Luce?
answer: I like it fine, Dad.

question: All your other teachers say you're happy, you're enthusiastic, you've always got your hand up...Mr. Linder says you don't participate unless he calls on you, and even then it's a one-word answer.
answer: I don't know what to say, Dad. I guess I'm just not...I don't know.

question: Luce, take a look at this book. This is exciting stuff. It's about who we are and what we want. Read what it says on the first page.
answer: "Property of Gilmore Junior High School."

question: The next page.
answer: "We, the People, of the United States, in order to form a more perfect union..."

question: See? Grabs you right off the bat. It's a page-turner.
answer: I can't wait.

question: Good, 'cause it's possible the subject might come up at dinner tonight.
answer: Do you see it as part of your job to torture me?

question: Hi, my name's Sydney Ellen Wade.
answer: He just needs your driver's license.

question: I'm from Virginia.
answer: He doesn't care.

question: I'm here for a meeting with Mr. MacInerney.
answer: He doesn't need to know that.

question: Forgive me, this is my first time at the White House. I'm trying to savor the Capra-esque quality.
answer: He doesn't know what Capra-esque means.

question: The day the government starts subsidizing private schools is the day we give up on public education. We're already doing the least we can do, but I can't think of anything better, so we'll go with this for now. Jerry, say hello to Linda for me. And if I don't see you again, have a good Thanksgiving. How're we doing?
answer: You're running four minutes ahead of schedule.

question: Ahead?
answer: Yes, sir.

question: Janie, this is unprecedented. I don't know what to do with myself.
answer: Mr. MacInerney asked me to remind you to pop your head in on--

question: Hardly an impressive distinction, A.J.
answer: Sydney, we should leave Mr. MacInerney alone now. He's already given us more time than--

question: Susan, Mr. MacInerney doesn't want us to leave, because Mr. MacInerney's not yet done what he needs to do today.
answer: Sir, Ms. Wade's been thrown into the deep end of the pool on her first day. She hasn't even had a chance to read the report of the Quebec Conference.

question: You're right. I haven't read it. If someone had asked me yesterday, I'd have told them the Quebec Conference was made up of six professional hockey teams. But what I do know is that it's time for the President to run for president again. Leon Kodak is as good as it gets when it comes to electoral strategy, and I'm certain he's told the President exactly what I'd tell him
answer: It's really time to--

question: Susan, I promise you, the White House Chief of Staff will not let us leave here until he's broken the bad news. The President's expecting our full support? The President's dreamin', A.J.
answer: Sydney!

question: Sydney?
answer: Yes, sir?

question: You got a second?
answer: Of course.

question: Sorry to keep you waiting.
answer: Mr. President--

question: Is it okay if I call you Sydney?
answer: Of course. Mr. President--

question: Have you ever been in the Oval Office?
answer: I've just been on the regular tour. It didn't include...

question: I hear it's pretty good.
answer: Mr. President, what you saw in there was nothing more than vanity run amok. I was showing off for a colleague who doesn't think very much of me. It'd be a real injustice for you to hold the GDC accountable for my behavior today. On top of which, I'm monumentally sorry for having insulted you like that.

question: Are you under the impression that I'm mad at you?
answer: Well...

question: Sydney, seldom does a day go by that I'm not burned in effigy.
answer: Not by a professional political operative standing 30 feet from the Oval Office.

question: No, I'll give you that.
answer: Mr. President--

question: Did you know that when the City Planners sat down to design Washington, D.C., their intention was to build a city that would intimidate and humble foreign heads of state? It's true.
answer: I didn't know that.

question: The White House has the single greatest home court advantage in the modern world.
answer: Learned that one the hard way.

question: Sydney, this bill is important to me.
answer: Yes, sir, I'll convey your message.

question: But you don't believe me?
answer: The GDC is asking for 20 percent, sir.

question: It's not gonna pass at 20 percent. It's a long shot at 10.
answer: How do you know that until you put the full weight of the White House behind--

question: Sydney, at 20 percent, we are 34 votes shy in the House. It can't be done. But I tell you what. I'll make you a deal with you. If you can get 24 votes, I'll get you the last 10.
answer: Twenty-four votes?

question: If you can swing 24 votes by the State of the Union, I'll promise you full White House support.
answer: Do I have your word on that, sir?

question: Absolutely. Listen, are you hungry? I skipped breakfast. You wanna have some coffee? A donut or something?
answer: Sir, I'm a little intimidated by my surroundings, and yes, I've gotten off to a rocky and somewhat stilted beginning, but don't let that diminish the weight of my message

question: You can't do that, Sydney.
answer: With all due respect, Mr. President, who's gonna stop me?

question: Well, if you go through that door, the United States Secret Service. That's my private office. You need to go out that way.
answer: Ah.

question: Richard...Richard, it wasn't funny. I acted like a college freshman at a protest rally.
answer: Tell him the part about walking out the wrong door.

question: Oh God, I forgot about that. No, Richard...Richard, I don't want to hear your Andrew Shepherd imitation...
answer: I wanna hear it.

question: I'm hanging up now, Richard... Tonight? I was gonna go to bed early and wake up when there's a new president. The President must think I'm a third- rate jerk.
answer: If he thinks you're a jerk, I'm sure he thinks you're a first-rate jerk.

question: I'll tell you one thing, boy. I regrouped, you gotta gimme that. I pulled it together at the end. I stood in the middle of the Oval Office and I made it very clear that from now on, he who doesn't take the GDC seriously does so at his peril!
answer: And then you walked out the wrong door.

question: Are you gonna be throwing that back at me the rest of my life?
answer: That's my current plan, yes.

question: That's gonna be Leo Solomon. He said he'd call at nine. Hello?
answer: Uh, hi, is this Sydney?

question: Leo? Andrew Shepherd. You're hilarious, Richard. You're a regular riot.
answer: Uhh...this isn't Richard, it's Andrew Shepherd.

question: Oh, really. Well, I'm so glad you called, because I forgot to tell you today what a nice ass you have. I'm also impressed that you were able to get my phone number, considering I don't have a phone. Good night, Richard.
answer: This used to be easier.

question: No way. I may choke in front of Shepherd, but Richard Reynolds I can handle. Hello?
answer: Sydney?

question: Are you learning-impaired?!
answer: Listen, do me a favor. Hang up the phone.

question: What?
answer: Hang up the phone. Then dial 456-1414. When you get the White House operator, give her your name and tell her you want to speak to the President.

question: It's not possible I did this twice in one day. My name's Sydney Ellen Wade. I'd like to--
answer: Hello.

question: Mr. President, I'm sure there's an appropriate thing to say at this moment. Probably some formal apology for the nice-ass remark would be in order. I just don't quite know how to word it.
answer: It's my fault. I shouldn't have called you at home. Should I call you at the office tomorrow?

question: No, sir, of course not. I mean -- yes, you can call me anytime you want -- this is fine. Right now is fine. When I said "of course not," I meat that...You know what? The hell with it -- I'm moving to another country.
answer: What did you mean when you said you don't have a phone.

question: I just moved to Washington over the weekend, and my apartment isn't ready yet. This is my sister's apartment. Come to think of it, how did you get this number?
answer: How did I get the number. That's a reasonable question. I don't know. Probably the FBI.

question: The FBI. Sure. 'Cause i-if you want to find someone and you're the president, that's who you would call.
answer: You know who else is good at that?

question: The C.I.A.?
answer: Well, yeah, but I was thinking of the Internal Revenue Service. They have computer files that...Well...I should stop stalling. As I'm sure you know, the French have elected themselves a new president, and we're having a formal state dinner at the White House, and I was wondering -- and you're under no obligation at all -- but I thought it might be fun... I was wondering if you maybe wanted to go...with me, and uh... there it is. That's why I was calling. Sydney? Sydney, Congress doesn't take this long to--

question: The President has asked me to join him in representing our country. I'm honored. I'm equal to the task. And I won't let you down, sir.
answer: Sydney, this is just a dinner. We're not gonna be doing espionage or anything.

question: No. Of course. I'm a little...uh...what do I do? I, I mean, where do I go? Should I meet you? Will you...
answer: I'm gonna have a very nice woman named Marsha Bridgeport call you. She's the White House Social Director, and she'll help you with anything you want. Now when she calls you and tells you her name is Marsha Bridgeport, it'll help if you give her the benefit of the doubt.

question: Of course.
answer: I'll see you Thursday night.

question: Mr. President, thank you for asking me. Really. This is a first for me.
answer: Me too.

question: Who's on Indiana? Excuse me. New people, I can't remember your names. Raise your hand if you're on Indiana. Put your hands down -- you're on Illinois.
answer: We've got Jarrett.

question: What?
answer: George Jarrett. He's ours. Solid "yes."

question: I don't believe it. You. New guy. "Jarrett, Democrat, Minnesota." Slide his name on over to "for." We just had his name laminated under "Undecided." How'd you get the fence pole out of his butt?
answer: I wish I could take credit. He just said, "Lewis, I support the President a hundred percent ." Not the bill, the President. We're gonna win this in a walk. It's like a kissing booth at a carnival. Give us a vote, get a photo-op with number 63. We should have gone after the handguns.

question: We gotta do one thing at a time.
answer: We don't have time to do one thing at a time.

question: That's a little tight, Luce.
answer: It's supposed to be tight. It's supposed to make you look regal.

question: Is it supposed to cut off the blood flow to my face?
answer: All done.

question: Not bad. Where did you learn how to do this?
answer: Social studies.

question: Very funny. Really, where did you learn?
answer: I don't know...I just guess...

question: Sweetie, did Mom teach you how to do this?
answer: Yeah.

question: Lucy, is this okay with you? My having dinner with a woman?
answer: It's totally okay.

question: Are you sure? Because if you want to talk about it...
answer: Dad, it's cool. Go for it.

question: You know, I'm a little nervous.
answer: You'll be fine. Just be yourself.

question: Be myself.
answer: And compliment her shoes.

question: Her shoes?
answer: Girls like that.

question: Thank you. I have no idea what I'm doing here.
answer: Sydney. Andrew Shepherd. We spoke on the phone.

question: Yes, sir. I remember. Sure. It's nice to see you again. I don't know what happened. One minute I was calling him a mockery of an environmental leader. The next minute I had a date. Got it.
answer: Mr. President, would allow me to introduce Sydney Ellen Wade of the Commonwealth of Virginia. Sydney, this is President Rene-Jean D'Astier and his wife Monique Danielle D'Astier of France.

question: Sydney, it sounds like our table's ready. Once we hit the bottom of the stairs, I gotta do a thing. You'll be escorted...
answer: They took me through it. Do you do this often, sir?

question: This is, actually, only our second State Dinner. The first was for the Emperor of Japan, who died shortly after that, so we stopped having them for a while, just in case.
answer: I meant do you go out on...do you-- often--do you--

question: Do I date a lot?
answer: Well, yeah.

question: No. How 'bout you?
answer: Me? Lately, I seem to be going out on a lot of first dates.

question: Then you're experienced at this.
answer: Oh yeah, you can ask me anything.

question: How are we doing so far?
answer: It's hard to say at this point. So far it's just your typical first date stuff.

question: Damn. And I wanted to find a way to be different from the other guys. By the way, nice shoes.
answer: Mr. President, the President and Mrs. D'Astier look bored. They're not talking to anybody.

question: They're hammered. Esther, do you speak French? I thought you spoke French. Great, next time Julius Caesar comes to town, you're our gal. Sydney, I don't suppose that you speak any--
answer: Monsieur le President, nous sommes tous habilles, nous avons ce merveilleux orchestre, une piece magnifique...comment se fait-il que les invites ne dansent pas?

question: That's my date.
answer: Really?

question: Sydney, you didn't dissolve the NATO treaty, did you?
answer: I just said that we're sitting in this beautiful room, listening to the music of this wonderful orchestra, and I wondered why nobody was dancing. There's a lesson there, Mr. President.

question: More beheadings at the White House? I'm sure he would, but I have a better idea. Would you like to dance?
answer: Uh, yeah, I guess. I mean, yes, sir, I'd love to. I don't know how you do it.

question: Arthur Murray. Six lessons.
answer: That's not what I mean. Two hundred pairs of eyes are focused on you right now, with two questions

question: Fine. Janie, can you get me the number of a local florist?
answer: I'll take care of it, sir. Where do you want them sent?

question: I want to do it myself. I just need the phone number.
answer: I don't understand.

question: I want the phone number of a florist.
answer: You just want the phone number?

question: Yeah.
answer: I don't understand, sir, is there--

question: I want to send some flowers, Janie. I want to do it myself. I don't want to staff it out, and I don't want to issue an Executive Order. I just want a phone number.
answer: I'll get it for you right away, sir.

question: I just need two minutes to make a call and I'll be right with you. Thank you, Janie.
answer: Who are we calling, sir?

question: I'm calling the Organization of the United Brotherhood of It's-None-of- Your-Damn-Business, Lewis. I'll be with you in a minute.
answer: Yes, sir.

question: Yeah, good morning. How do I get an outside line? Really? That's simple. Thank you.
answer: Janie?

question: Leo, you wanted to see me?
answer: So there I was, thinking maybe I should give Sydney a call. She's new in town, doesn't know many people...

question: Leo--
answer: Then I picked up the Times--

question: It was crazy. He called me at home.
answer: What's going on?

question: Nothing. It was innocent. His cousin got the flu at the last minute.
answer: Did you sleep with him?

question: What?
answer: Did you sleep--

question: That's none of your business, Leo.
answer: Yeah, it is, Sydney.

question: You wanna tell me how my personal life in any way--
answer: Because when it's the President, it's not personal. Sydney, I hired your reputation. I hired a pit bull, not a prom queen.

question: That's unfair.
answer: It's incredibly unfair. But you've spent a lot of time over the year telling me the trouble with the environmental lobby is that we don't understand the fundamental truth that politics is perception. This is a bad time to develop ignorance.

question: You're making way too much of this.
answer: Am I? This is your time, Sydney. You're sitting at the grown-ups' table. You have a chance to get everything you want -- run a national campaign, be a major player inside the party. But this relationship had better go all the way, because with the leader of the free world there is no halfway. Politics is perception, and if thing don't work out, the amount of time it'll take you to go from being a hired gun to a cocktail party joke can be clocked with an egg timer.

question: So he had some staff flunky send me a fruit basket.
answer: He wrote the note himself.

question: I'm sure he didn't take the time to--
answer: The messenger said he was waiting in the Oval Office for ten minutes while the President wrote the card.

question: Okay, listen, so he-- --it took him ten minutes to write a card?!
answer: Apparently he went through several drafts.

question: I sure hope the Sydney issue refers in some way to a problem we're having with Australia, because if it's anything else...
answer: Mr. President, Ms. Wade is here to see you.

question: Tell her she can come right in. I'm finished here.
answer: Yes, sir.

question: There is no Sydney issue.
answer: Thanks for seeing me on such short notice.

question: No problem. Did you get the ham?
answer: I got the ham, yes. Thank you very much.

question: I wanted to send you flowers, but there seem to be some kinks in the system. I'm really glad you stopped by. I had such a good time last night.
answer: So did I. It's just that...

question: I'm delivering a luncheon speech at the Governor's Conference this morning. I'm sorry to--
answer: No, no, that's fine. I just stopped by to...

question: Are you free for dinner tomorrow night?
answer: Dinner?

question: Casual. In the Residence. Without the United Nations. My daughter'll be with us, so it may seem like the United--
answer: I'd love to meet Lucy, but...

question: She's gonna like you. Excuse me -- Jeff!
answer: Actually, I have some concerns that--

question: I can't do this. Either one. I have to be in and out. Stackhouse wants to talk about grazing rights. Trust me. Sorry. You have concerns.
answer: Yes. Not many. A few. One. I have one concern.

question: Does it having anything to do with one of us being the President?
answer: You like to make jokes about this, but--

question: I am not mocking you, honest. I'm just a guy asking a girl over for a meal.
answer: What's that?

question: My ride's here.
answer: Leo Solomon has serious concerns about my exploring a social, you know, scenario, with the President of the United States.

question: Yeah, well, when you put it that way, it doesn't sound that great to me either.
answer: It's just not--

question: Are you Ms. Wade?
answer: Sydney.

question: Lucy Shepherd.
answer: Nice to meet you.

question: My dad told me to tell you he's on the phone with his dentist and that I should behave myself and entertain you till he gets here.
answer: Your father's on the phone with his dentist?

question: No. He told me to tell you he's on the phone with his dentist. He wants you to think he's a regular guy.
answer: Who is he on the phone with?

question: The Prime Minister of Israel.
answer: They're probably not discussing his teeth.

question: No. They're talking about that abbreviation I can never remember.
answer: C-STAD?

question: Yeah.
answer: Capricorn Surface To Air Defense.

question: Let meat loaf night begin.
answer: Everything all right with your teeth?

question: My teeth?
answer: The dentist.

question: Oh, right. I've got a cavity in my upper bicuspid region.
answer: You've got a short-range weapons system outside Tel Aviv.

question: This is a nightmare. This is a social studies nightmare.
answer: They're doing a mock Congress. Each kid is playing one of the original delegates, and they debate the Amendments. Now what's not fun about that?

question: G'night, Dad.
answer: G'night, sweetheart.

question: She's wonderful.
answer: She's her mother.

question: She's you.
answer: Would you like the 25-cent tour?

question: I thought C-STAD wasn't gonna be operational until January.
answer: It was ready ahead of schedule. We've just been waiting for the personnel.

question: The Israelis?
answer: No, our guys. We've sent a team of Army instructors to train the Israelis.

question: It's not the dish--
answer: Yeah, it is. It's the room with all the dishes.

question: It's the China Room.
answer: I'm more of a West Wing President. If you're curious about the mansion, there's probably a book you can get--

question: There're about seven-thousand books. I'll get one for you.
answer: Sydney.

question: Mr. President -- have you ever noticed how similar the Van Buren flatware is to the Buchanan flatware?
answer: Do you think there will ever come a time when you can stand in a room with me and not think of me as the President?

question: This isn't a state of mind. You are the President. And when I'm in a room with you, oval or any other shape, I'm always gonna be a lobbyist, and you'll always be the President.
answer: I got news for you, Sydney. As a lobbyist, you would never be alone in a room with the President.

question: You think this is a good idea?
answer: Probably not. Excuse me.

question: No...of course.
answer: Listen--

question: Is anything wrong?
answer: I'm sorry, we're going to have to cut our evening short. The Libyans have just bombed C-STAD. I'll try to call you tomorrow. Can you show Ms. Wade out.

question: I'm sorry, we're going to have to cut our evening short. The Libyans have just bombed C-STAD. I'll try to call you tomorrow. Can you show Ms. Wade out.
answer: The response scenario's in place... ...The F-18's are fired up on the Kimitz and the Kitty Hawk. They're just waiting for your attack order, Mr. President.

question: And we're gonna hit Libyan Intelligence Headquarters? Libyan I.H.Q's in the middle of downtown Tripoli -- are we gonna hit anything else? Are we gonna miss? How many people work in that building?
answer: We've been all through--

question: How many people work in the damn building? The fewest. What shift puts the fewest people in the building? The night shift, right? What time does the night crew go on? A.J.? Someday somebody's going to have to explain to me the virtue of a proportional response.
answer: Mr. President?

question: The last thing I want to do is put the Lybians center stage.
answer: I think it's a great idea, sir. You know Rumson's gonna be talking about your lack of military service.

question: This isn't about Rumson. What I did tonight was not about political gain.
answer: But it can be, sir. What you did tonight was very presidential.

question: Leon, somewhere in Libyan right now there's a janitor working the night shift at the Libyan Intelligence Headquarters. He's going about his job 'cause he has no idea that in about an hour he's gonna die in a massive explosion. He's just going about his job 'cause he has no idea that an hour ago I gave an order to have him killed. You just saw me do the least presidential thing I do.
answer: yes, sir.

question: No. We did everything but show them the blueprints. The hardware was sitting in a airplane hangar for a month. They didn't hit it until the Yes, we'd just finished dinner.
answer: Last question.

question: We don't have a relationship. We just had dinner. Folks, a lot of people got killed last night. Let's try to keep our eyes on the ball, okay?
answer: That was my fault, sir. We should have prepped you for that.

question: There's nothing that needs prepping. A.J., let's meet with the leadership after we meet with the Security Council.
answer: "Newsweek" is begging for ten minutes today. Any ten minutes you got.

question: This box just says "Miscellaneous." Is this bedroom miscellaneous or kitchen miscellaneous? Sydney?
answer: Why did I have to kiss him?

question: You kissed him?
answer: Yeah.

question: You didn't' tell me that.
answer: I kissed him.

question: Where?
answer: On the mouth.

question: Where in the White House?!
answer: In the dish room.

question: The dish room?
answer: The China Room.

question: Then what happened?
answer: He had to go and attack Libya.

question: It's always something.
answer: I've gotta nip this in the bud. This has catastrophe written all over it.

question: In what language?! Sydney, this man is the leader of the free world. He's brilliant, he's funny, he's handsome, and he's an above-average dancer. Isn't it possible our standards are just a tad high? Answer the phone.
answer: It's him.

question: Answer the phone.
answer: He's gonna ask me to come over there.

question: Answer the phone.
answer: I don't want to go over there.

question: Answer the phone.
answer: All right. But I'm gonna end it on the phone. I'm not gonna go over there. CUT TO: I just came over here to tell you why I can't see you anymore.

question: All right. But I'm gonna end it on the phone. I'm not gonna go over there. CUT TO: I just came over here to tell you why I can't see you anymore.
answer: Thanks, Coop.

question: Look, I know you've had a tough day.
answer: Not as tough as some. You want a drink? Lemme take your coat.

question: Mr. President, this isn't gonna work.
answer: Sure it will. You button the top button, and it doesn't fall off the hanger.

question: That's not what I...
answer: I didn't think so. Listen...

question: I've really enjoyed the time we've spent together, but this has catastrophe written all over it. Please, Mr. President, don't pursue me outside the political arena.
answer: Well, I have no intention of pursuing you inside the political arena, so that leaves everything out, and that's unacceptable to me.

question: If I were on your staff, I would tell you that the absolute worst thing you can do coming into an election year is to open yourself up to character attacks, and the fastest way to do that is to prance around like the playboy of the Western world.
answer: Let's clear up a couple of things. Number 1

question: Yes, of course, but if you'll follow the immutable--
answer: Why is that, by the way?

question: Why's that?
answer: Why aren't you on my staff?

question: You can't afford me.
answer: How much do you make?

question: More than you do, Mr. President.
answer: The name's Andy. How much money do you make?

question: What the hell does it matter how much money I--
answer: You would raise your voice to the President?

question: I'm only thinking about the health of your Presidency. You think this morning's press conference was the end of it? Bob Rumson's gotta be drooling over this.
answer: Are you attracted to me?

question: I beg your pardon?
answer: I asked if--

question: That's not the issue--
answer: Well, I tell you what. Let's make it the issue. Let's try something new, 'cause I know that most couples, when they're first getting together, are inclined to slam on the brakes because they're concerned about Bob Rumson's drool.

question: You're not most people.
answer: You know what your problem is?

question: What's my problem?
answer: Sex and nervousness.

question: Sex and nervousness is my problem.
answer: Yes. Last night when we were looking at the different place settings in the dish room, I realized that those place settings were provided by the First Ladies. And I'll bet none of those First Ladies were nervous about having sex with their President husbands. And you know why?

question: No, but I'm sure you'll explain it to me.
answer: I will. Because they weren't presidents when they met them. Not the case here.

question: Ahhhhhh.
answer: You see what I'm getting at?

question: Yes. May I use your bathroom for a moment?
answer: Sure. It's right through there.

question: I want to freshen up.
answer: As you pass through, you'll see a large closet on your left. And if you feel comfortable, hang up your coat, and when you come back I'll have fixed up a drink, we'll sit on the couch, and I will explain to you my plan.

question: You have a plan? Don't make me wait. You're on a roll.
answer: Okay. You're attracted to me, but the idea of physical intimacy is uncomfortable because you only know me as the President. It's not always gonna be that way, and the reason I know that is because there was a moment last night when you were with me and not the President, and I know what a big step that was for you. So, Sydney, I'm in no rush. Here's my plan Perhaps I didn't properly explain the fundamentals of the "Slow Down" plan.

question: You explained it great.
answer: Are you nervous?

question: No.
answer: Good. My nervousness exists on several levels. Number 1 -- and this is in no particular order -- I haven't done this in a pretty long time. Number 2

question: The most powerful man in the world?
answer: Exactly, thank you. Just so you remember that's a political distinction that comes with the office. I mean, if Eisenhower were here instead of me he'd be dead by now. And number three...

question: Yeah...put him through. Lewis, it is 5:00 a.m. You gotta get yourself a life, man. Yeah...all right. Sydney?
answer: Hi.

question: What are you doing?
answer: I wanted to leave the building before the press corps got here.

question: I have those same thoughts every day of my life. Say, you know Lewis Rothschild, don't you? Well, he's...
answer: Sure. Boy, Lewis'd go nuts if he knew I'd spent the night.

question: ...on his way up.
answer: What?

question: They're camped out at every exit.
answer: Who? Who's camped out?

question: The press.
answer: The press is camped out?

question: You shoulda taken a cab, Sydney.
answer: They know my car?!

question: Thanks, A.J.
answer: I'm sorry about all this. We'll do it better next time.

question: I'm no expert, but I thought we did it pretty good this time.
answer: No, I mean...

question: I know. I had a good time.
answer: Me, too. I'll call you. I'll be in Panama, but I'll call you.

question: I'd like that. Bye.
answer: All right...okay...this is good.

question: I agree a hundred and ten percent, Mrs. Harper. That's why I'm up here in the dead of winter talkin' about it with you folks. That's very generous of you, ma'am, and I'm gonna take that money off your hands right now. What do you got for me, Stu?
answer: Call me Santa Claus, Senator. She's got an FBI file.

question: Shit, Stu, my mother's got an FBI file.
answer: I've got art. It's a demonstration outside the Department of Commerce. The picture's old, and a lot of the faces are obscured by the smoke, but this is Sydney right there in front.

question: Oh man...tell me the smoke is coming from what it looks like it's coming from.
answer: Yes, sir -- it's burning flag.

question: I understand, Congressman...Of course you need to deliberate. I know the fact that there isn't any heavy industry in your district doesn't make this decision any easier. But we met three weeks ago, and at the end of that meeting you said that you were leaning our way but that you wanted to sleep on it. Since I haven't heard from you since then, the only conclusion I can reach is that you haven't slept in 21 days.
answer: Ask him about his position on stateboard for Hawaii.

question: Harry, think like a father for a second. Wouldn't you like your kids to be able to take a deep breath when they're 30? Thank you. You're doing the right thing. Tote board's heavy.
answer: How's this?

question: That's better!
answer: Hey, Syd, I saw on your schedule you're gonna meet with McSorley, McCluskey and Shane.

question: Yeah, the Motown Three said they'd give me 30 minutes next week.
answer: Sydney, these are people who represent people who make cars for a living.

question: Yeah.
answer: Cars, you understand, run on gasoline.

question: Hey, I know it's a long shot, but if I can get one of them, it'll be a huge payoff in visibility.
answer: Well, if we're gonna try, we should do some prep work. You wanna order in?

question: I can't work tonight. I'm having dinner at the White House. We can start early tomorrow.
answer: Okay. I'm having lunch at the Kremlin, so we'll have to, you know, start real early...

question: Good night, David.
answer: ...in order for me to catch the morning plane to Moscow.

question: We've got a small problem.
answer: It could've been a small problem. It's now at the very least a medium- sized--

question: Robin sees it as a problem. I see it as a opportunity.
answer: It could've been an opportunity if we'd caught it...

question: We caught it.
answer: At 5:45. Five-forty-five doesn't do me any good, Lewis. Five-forty-five, network news is in makeup.

question: Let me see if I've got this
answer: See, I think it's important, when we deal with it, that we--

question: Don't deal with it.
answer: Excuse me?

question: They're trying to get us to swing at a pitch in the dirt. No one ever wins these fights. It'll go away.
answer: I'm not sure that's the wisest--

question: It's terrific, Beth. I love it.
answer: I can't believe I'm loaning you clothes. I thought you owned every piece of clothing there was.

question: Work clothes. I always have dinner at the White House wearing a suit. I thought a dress would be nice.
answer: Go ahead, try it on. I brought earrings, too.

question: Hello... I'm just trying on dresses. How do you feel about leather?
answer: I feel terrible, but I have to cancel our date tonight.

question: Another woman?
answer: No, I've gotta go to St. Louis and avert a massive airline strike.

question: Boys, if I had a nickel for every time I heard that one.
answer: Thanks for understanding. I'll call you tonight Boy, I hate doing that. She was trying on dresses.

question: Well, I say it with a great deal of charm.
answer: Look! Look! There it is! Carmen's House of Flowers! We gotta stop.

question: What?
answer: I gotta get her flowers.

question: Coop, I'm gonna hop out at that flower shop.
answer: No, he's not hopping. Sir, no hopping. Stay in the car. I'll get the flowers.

question: Then it's not personal.
answer: Let the agents do a security sweep. We don't know who's in there.

question: You think there's a florist who's planning an assassination on the off-chance that I'd be stopping by?
answer: It's possible.

question: What do Lewis and Robin think?
answer: Brutus and Cassius? They want me to get into the character debate and mix it up.

question: Lewis and Robin are very smart.
answer: Sydney says you guys are really stupid.

question: I didn't say that!
answer: She's questioning your loyalty.

question: It's a good thing he cleared that up, 'cause the crowd was gettin' ready to buy some AMWAY products.
answer: His number are climbing.

question: Sydney, his number have nowhere to go but up.
answer: What about yours?

question: We're fine. We'll be back up in the 60's once I get the votes for the crime bill. Say, what're you doing this weekend?
answer: I've got some work I was gonna bring home. Why?

question: The negotiations are going pretty well here. It looks like the nation's going to keep on flying. Lucy's sleeping over at a friend's house Saturday night.
answer: What'd you have in mind?

question: Have you ever been to Camp David?
answer: Camp David? Sure. I used to go there all the time, but then they changed chefs and...

question: It's sass, right? You're sassing me.
answer: Yes.

question: I'll have a car pick you up Saturday morning.
answer: Do you ever get used to helicopters dropping you off at your front door?

question: How many "e"s in "kaleidoscope"?
answer: I guess you do. Oh good God.

question: What?
answer: I'm looking at your college transcripts. This isn't human. Nobody gets this many "A's." You were like a Stepford student.

question: Are you still reading that ridiculous biography?
answer: Actually I finished Andrew Shepherd

question: Seven-trillion-dollar communications system at my disposal, you'd think I'd be able to find out if the Packers won.
answer: Oh, Andy...C-minus in Women's Studies?

question: My God. He's making this up as he goes along.
answer: I'm so sorry about this, Sydney.

question: Oh, man. My father heard that.
answer: You gotta tell him to turn a deaf ear.

question: My father doesn't have a deaf ear. He hears fine out of both. So do I. So does my sister, so do my friends. You're the only one who seems to--
answer: Sydney, I can't challenge the school bully to a fight just because he picked on my girlfriend.

question: I'm not asking you to. I can take care of myself. This isn't about me. How can you keep quiet? How do you have patience for people who claim they love America but clearly can't stand Americans?
answer: I have one more election left, Sydney. I don't have the luxury of losing my patience.

question: I want to say something, but I'm gonna fumble it a little bit, so I'd just like you to wait till I'm done before you respond. I'm in love with you. I'm certain of it. And I want to be with you more than anything. But maybe things would be better for you if I disappeared for a while.
answer: Things will be better when I pass a crime bill. And Sydney, if you disappeared, I'd find you. Is that a fact? If I'm not mistaken, Gill, I think the courts ruled on Title 9 about 20 years ago. Well, it's a world gone mad, Gill.

question: Merry Christmas, A.J. I got stuck on DePont Circle. I can never remember which lane I'm supposed to take. Then I got cut off by this idiot cab driver who starts screaming at me like it's my fault.
answer: Hi, Syd. Get stuck on DuPont Circle again?

question: It's not funny. I hate that place. Can't you declare it a Federal Disaster Area or something?
answer: I'll look into it.

question: Ahhh...I had a terrible meeting today. Totally lost my cool with McSorley, McCluskey and Shane.
answer: You went to see the Motown Three?

question: I pitched 'em the hill.
answer: The woman knows no fear. She'd lobby the Carolinas to the American Lung Association.

question: It was a disaster. Well, congratulations, fellas, you're outta the cellar. McSorley told me the only thing on the President's domestic agenda they were more committed to defeating than the crime bill was the fossil fuel package. No, I'm not kidding. It's funny that he used the same words.
answer: I don't think the Pep Boys know too many words.

question: I'm gonna get a drink and shake this off. When I come back, I'll have Christmas spirit.
answer: Okay.

question: Is something wrong?
answer: No, I was...I was thinking about-- nothing.

question: I'll be back in a minute.
answer: No, the GDC's political director didn't tell us anything. Sydney Wade told her boyfriend and her boyfriend's best friend that she had a lousy day. I made a promise, A.J. I made it with Sydney. Yeah, well, this is all academic anyway. We're not going to need those votes.

question: Congressman, the assault weapons are gone.
answer: The bill is priced to move, see. The President's coattail's are gonna have room for you, Congressman, you leave that to us. I wouldn't say he's in a free--

question: The well is drying up. The President's gotta make a move or we're gonna die fast and quiet.
answer: What if I do a new poll? We give him detailed public opinion.

question: This was delicious. Thank you. Is there any left?
answer: Tons. I didn't think you liked it.

question: Are you kidding me, of course I did. But actually it's not for me. The agent who checked the food thought it was delicious, and I sort of told him I'd bring him some if there was any left.
answer: So you didn't like it.

question: No, I loved it.
answer: You're lying.

question: No, I'm not.
answer: You are. I can tell when you're holding something back. You do a thing with your face.

question: When have you seen me do a thing with my face?
answer: Two days before I met you. You gave a speech for the Daughters of the American Revolution. I was there.

question: You were?
answer: You remember the speech?

question: Vaguely.
answer: "American can no longer afford to pretend that they live in a great society."

question: Ah.
answer: There was supposed to be something else after that, wasn't there?

question: How did you know?
answer: I told you. The face.

question: Wow...what's the occasion?
answer: You're looking at a lady who's two votes shy of the promised land.

question: Two votes?
answer: I got Pennybaker. That got me Cass and Zimmer.

question: That's great, Sydney. I mean it. That's great work.
answer: Well, I'm not there yet.

question: Look, no matter what happens, you have every right to be proud of yourself.
answer: I'll be proud when I see you sign the bill.

question: Yeah, well...
answer: Andy.

question: Yeah?
answer: You're doing that thing with your face.

question: How're the numbers?
answer: Bad.

question: How bad?
answer: Forty-one. Character across the board.

question: Who is Lewis on with?
answer: Jarrett. He's trying to keep his finger in the dam.

question: We said as a last resort.
answer: We're there, sir. The State of the Union is 48 hours away.

question: No. Come on. There's gotta be three votes someplace else.
answer: There isn't.

question: Bullshit, Leon. There's gotta be somebody we haven't--
answer: There isn't, sir.

question: Storch.
answer: I beg your pardon?

question: What about Storch?
answer: Storch is a "no."

question: Wagner.
answer: No.

question: Sobel.
answer: No.

question: Clark.
answer: No.

question: Not that Clark, the one from Indiana.
answer: That one too, sir.

question: She is one vote away, A.J. It's important legislation that for the first time has a legitimate chance. I think she deserves every possible opportunity to--
answer: She? You meant "it," didn't you, sir? You meant the "important legislation" deserves every opportunity.

question: You got something to say to me?
answer: Respectfully, sir. I think we should examine the new poll for more than its value as a box score.

question: Examine what? They don't like that I'm going out with Sydney.
answer: It's not that simple, sir. I think this poll helps bribg a murky problem into specific relief.

question: Whose problem we talking about, Lewis? Yours? You worried about your job? This poll isn't talking about my Presidency. This poll is talking about my life. Two hundred and sixty-four million people have decided--
answer: Mr. President, two hundred and sixty- four million people don't give a damn about your life. They give a damn about their own. Mr. President, you've raised a daughter almost entirely on your own, and she's terrific. What does it say to you that in the last seven weeks, 59 percent of this country has begun to question your family values? Oh yes, he does, A.J. I'm a citizen, this is my president, and in this country it is not only permissible to question our leaders, it is our responsibility. But you already know that, Mr. President, because you have a deeper love of this country than any man I've ever known, and I want to know what it says to you that in the past seven weeks 59 percent of Americans have begun to question your patriotism?

question: Look, if people want to listen to Bob Rumson--
answer: They don't have a choice! Rob Rumson's the only one doing the talking. People want leadership. And in the absence of genuine leadership, they will listen to anyone who steps up to the microphone. They want leadership, Mr. President. They're so thirsty for it, they'll crawl through the desert toward a mirage, and when they discover there's no water, they'll drink the sand.

question: I want to go on the record and apologize for my attitude toward you since your arrival.
answer: I didn't notice. Was there an attitude?

question: I think I have a lot of pent-up hostility.
answer: Well--

question: I wonder who I can blame it on.
answer: I'm not really qualified to--

question: Leo needs to see you.
answer: Tell him to get over here. It's a party.

question: He needs to see you in his office.
answer: It can't wait?

question: Sounds good.
answer: It's progressive.

question: I'll say.
answer: Hey, Dad, what's wrong with Sydney? You guys have a fight?

question: What do you mean?
answer: She seemed pretty--

question: You saw her?
answer: She's here.

question: Where?
answer: In your room. Why is she mad?

question: Don't worry about it.
answer: Were you a dork?

question: Practice your music.
answer: If you were a dork, you should say you're sorry. Girls like that.

question: Syd?
answer: Have you seen a gray cableknit sweater?

question: A grey...sweater? No. I called you at the office, but...
answer: It's Beth's. I wore it here one time, and I didn't want to leave it.

question: Where were you going?
answer: I'm going home, and then I'm going to Hartford.

question: Connecticut?
answer: Yes. Do you know if it was sent with your dry cleaning by any--

question: What's in Connecticut?
answer: Richard Reynolds' campaign. He may be able to get me a job.

question: When did you decide to get a new job?
answer: Not long after Leo Solomon fired me from my old one. Beth's gonna kill me. She loves that--

question: Why did he fire you?
answer: Total failure to achieve any of the objectives for which I was hired. I told him he was being unreasonable. After all, I did get to dance with the President and ride in Air Force One a couple of times. But you know those prickly environmentalists. It's always gonna be something with them. If it's not clean air, then it's clean water. Like it isn't good enough that I'm on the cover of People Magazine.

question: I'll call him.
answer: You'll call him? You mean you'll call him yourself? Personally? It'll come from the President? That's a great idea. I think you should call Leo and make a deal. He hires me back for, say, 72 days. I go around scaring the hell out of Congress, making them think that the President's about to drive through a very damaging and costly bill. They'll believe me, right, 'cause I'm the President's Friday Night Girl. Now I don't know if you can dip into this well twice, especially since I've lost all credibility in politics, but you never know, I might just be able to pull it off again. I might be able to give you just the leverage you need to pass some ground-breaking piece of crime legislation -- like a mandatory three-day waiting period before a five-year-old can buy an Uzi. Fuck the sweater -- she'll have to learn to live with disappointment.

question: What do you think went on here today?
answer: I know exactly what went on here today. I got screwed. You saw the poll, you needed the crime bill, you couldn't get it on your own, so I got screwed.

question: The environment got screwed. Nothing happened to you today, Sydney. Governing is choosing. Governing is prioritizing. I've made no secret of the fact that the crime bill was my top priority.
answer: Well then, congratulations. It's only taken you three years to put together crime prevention legislation that has no hope of preventing crime.

question: Sydney. Please. I don't want to lose you over this.
answer: Mr. President, you got bigger problems than losing me. You just lost my vote.

question: Richard Reynolds' district office. She's thinking of running his campaign. Four in the corner. Hartford. The insurance capital of the world. Have a good time, Syd. You handling me, A.J.? Good. 14 in the side. Excuse me. Has he lied?! Has Rumson lied in the last seven weeks? Other than not knowing the difference between Harvard and Stanford, has he said something that isn't true? Am I not a Commander-in-Chief who's never served in the military? Am I not opposed to a Constitutional amendment banning flag burning? Am I not an unmarried father who was sharing a bed with a liberal lobbyist down the hall from my twelve-year-old daughter? I don't think you win elections by telling 59 percent of the people that they are. Don't-- Is the view pretty good from the cheap seats, A.J.? It occurs to me that in 25 years I've never seen your name on a ballot. Why have you always been standing a pace behind me? Fuck you. Have Lewis put the final drafts of the State of the Union and the Crime Bill announcement on my desk in the morning. If Mary hadn't died...would we have won three years ago? If we'd had to go through a character debate three years ago, would we have won? Yeah. You're not hungry?
answer: This is oatmeal.

question: Yeah.
answer: We never have oatmeal.

question: It's good for you.
answer: I'm from Wisconsin. I need food.

question: You're not from Wisconsin. I'm from Wisconsin. You've lived in Washington your whole life. How are you doing in your Constitutional debates?
answer: We're done.

question: You're done?
answer: We ratified it last week.

question: Oh...well...that's good. Why didn't you tell me?
answer: It's not a big deal, Dad.

question: Okay, I give up. I don't care why you're not happy in social studies. I care about why you're not talking to me about why you're not happy in social studies.
answer: Dad, I'm perfectly--

question: You're not perfectly happy. You don't think I know when something's bothering you?
answer: Damnit, Dad!

question: Hey!
answer: You know--

question: Talk to me.
answer: Look-- --sometimes when you talk, you say things I disagree with.

question: Almost every time I talk, I say things you disagree with.
answer: I mean politically.

question: Politically?
answer: Yes.

question: What do you mean?
answer: Yes. Okay. Yes. Sometimes, I mean, I'm not sure. You know a lot more than I do -- but still, I have these feelings, and I don't think they're wrong. Like, okay, for instance, I'm not so sure it's all right to burn a flag. I mean, it really bothers a lot of people, and I don't know why you think it's okay. I hear Senator Rumson talk, and some of the things he says sounds right to me, and I think, "God, am I like Bob Rumson?! I mean, Dad thinks he's a jerk. Dad hates this guy! Why am I agreeing with him" And then I think, "Well, maybe I'm not really like Bob Rumson, but maybe I'm not like Dad either." But the point is I'm the President's kid, and people pay attention to what I say, and if I say something different from what you say, it'll be embarrassing for you. So I can't just get up in social studies class and say whatever I want.

question: Stand up please. I want you to pay very close attention to what happens now. In your lifetime, you will never embarrass me. It could never happen. You're not the President's daughter, Lucy, you're mine. And no one's gonna vote me out of that job. You're my daughter, and everything else is a distant second. School is for you, Lucy. You say what you want. The only thing you have to do to make me happy is come home at the end of the day. One more thing. I don't dislike Senator Rumson because of his political views. And even if you voted for everything he would vote for, that wouldn't make you like him. There's a fundamental difference between you and the Bob Rumsons of the world.
answer: What's that?

question: The difference is that he says he loves America. Saying you love America is easy. What takes character -- and this is what you have-- What takes character is loving Americans. Luce, I gotta go.
answer: Dad, is everything all right?

question: Everything's fine. I'm just a little late for work. Somebody get my daughter some food! The girl's from Wisconsin, for cryin' out loud! Yes, he will. 'Morning.
answer: Good morning, Mr. President.

question: That's all right, you can keep your seats. For the last couple of months, Senator Rumson has suggested that being president of this country was, to a certain extent, about character...
answer: Lewis...call A.J. and come on down here...I don't know, but something's happening.

question: ...and although I have not been willing to engage in his attacks on me, I've been here three years and three days, and I can tell you without hesitation For the record Why would a senator, his party's most powerful spokesman and a candidate for president, choose to reject upholding the Constitution? If you can answer that question, then, folks, you're smarter than I am, because I didn't understand it until a couple of minutes ago. Everybody knows American isn't easy. America is advanced citizenship. You gotta want it bad, 'cause it's gonna put up a fight. It's gonna say, "You want free speech? Let's see you acknowledge a man whose words make your blood boil, who's standing center stage and advocating, at the top of his lungs, that which you would spend a lifetime opposing at the top of yours. You want to claim this land as the land of the free, then the symbol of your country can't just be a flag; the symbol also has to be one of its citizens exercising his right to burn that flag in protest." Show me that, defend that, celebrate that in your classrooms. Then you can stand up and sing about the land of the free. I've known Bob Rumson for years. I've been operating under the assumption that the reason Bob devotes so much time and energy to shouting at the rain was that he simply didn't get it. Well, I was wrong. Bob's problem isn't that he doesn't get it. Bob's problem is that he can't sell it. Nobody has ever won an election by talking about what I was just talking about. This is a country made up of people with hard jobs that they're terrified of losing. The roots of freedom are of little or no interest to them at the moment. We are a nation afraid to go out at night. We're a society that has assigned low priority to education and has looked the other way while our public schools have been decimated. We have serious problems to solve, and we need serious men to solve them. And whatever your particular problem is, friend, I promise you, Bob Rumson is not the least bit interested in solving it. He is interested in two things and two things only You want a character debate? Fine, but you better stick with me, 'cause Sydney Ellen Wade is way out of your league. I've loved two women in my life. I lost one to cancer, and I lost the other 'cause I was so busy keeping my job I forgot to do my job. Well that ends right now. Tomorrow morning the White House is sending a bill to Congress for its consideration. It's White House Resolution 455, an energy bill requiring a 20 percent reduction of the emission of fossil fuels over the next ten years. It is by far the most aggressive stride ever taken in the fight to reverse the effects of global warming. The other piece of legislation is the crime bill. As of today it no longer exists. I'm throwing it out. I'm throwing it out and writing a law that makes sense. You cannot address crime prevention without getting rid of assault weapons and handguns. I consider them a threat to national security, and I will go door to door if I have to, but I'm gonna convince Americans that I'm right, and I'm gonna get the guns. We've got serous problems, and we need serious men, and if you want to talk about character, Bob, you'd better come at me with more than a burning flag and a membership card. If you want to talk about character and American values, fine. Just tell me where and when, and I'll show up. This is a time for serious men, Bob, and your fifteen minutes are up. My name's Andrew Shepherd, and I am the President.
answer: Any questions?

question: Lewis.
answer: Sir.

question: Things have been a little rough between us lately.
answer: I know sir, I'm sorry.

question: Don't stop what you're doing.
answer: That's kind of you, sir, but I realize I've been a little insensitive about some personal...

question: No, you were right. Two hundred and sixty-four million people don't give a damn about my life.
answer: Just so you know I've never been one of them, Mr. President.
